title: From Bauhaus to Your House
content:
{From Bauhaus to Your House}   
   
Has anyone read this book? What are your thoughts?   
Although I still think the world of the Bauhaus greats in general, the book offers a very convincing "other side of the story". The book seems to kind of make the point that in trying to "start from zero" they ended up with zero.   
   
Are there other books anyone knows of off-hand dealing with the negative aspects of bauhaus?

comments.content: sorry, it's from Bauhaus to Our House. (by Tom Wolfe)
Hitler was right, Bauhaus sucks, I would like to read the book.

Not exactly the response I was hoping for.   
Wolfe starts off comparing it to the Vienna Secession, how they both had their own singular building, which was the center for the "compound" out of which all the rules and ideas came from.   
   
His main critique is that it became so important and so highly regarded that an attempt at anything else was considered "bourgeois", and almost even spiritually wrong. (The book makes many religious references.) Another main point is how clients didn't ever actually like the designs they were paying for, but kept paying for them anyways, allowing the designers/architects to dictate to them what was good and bad.   
   
It deals mostly with architecture, rather than type or any other art, but certainly the applications can be made. It talks about how even Philip Johnson used to like to be called "Mies van der Johnson" and that even the architects who realized the flaw of everything looking "bauhaus" had to become part of the system in order to be taken seriously and still move away from it (Robert Venturi.)   
   
It has a really striking picure that I hadn't seen before of one section of Yale (a museum I think) which was done in gothic revival, next to an addition in bauhaus style, and it looks rather pathethic, even though it is "simple" and "clean" which is still how people like to describe "good" design, and think that if they say, "this is good because it is simple" that they are automatically justified.   
And here's a random thought; I really hope the new WTC design isn't just another "glass box" but is instead something really creative. If we keep rebuilding mimics of the past we aren't really making much progress. (Maybe this relates to redoing old typefaces?)   
Anyhow, good book. Would like to read others like it.

Well, I've never been there, and I agree that this kind of 'automatic' link 'simple=good' is wrong. But this building designed by Kahn is certainly not 'pathetic'. IIRC, it has some great (complex) ceiling devices for natural lighting (it's a museum) in the intern spaces. The building is only apparently simple. And Kahn is far from the Bauhaus style, he was [not](http://web.archive.org/web/20050810074530/http:/www.greatbuildings.com/buildings/Institute_of_Public_Admin.html) a 'modernist'.   
   
\> If we keep rebuilding mimics of the past we aren't really making much progress.   
   
Of course, completely agreed. (But then, what to say about 'post-modern' architecture? Robert Venturi? 'Learning from Las Vegas?' ;-)   
   
   
   
William:   
\> I agree with Wolfe that the Bauhaus had mainly a disasterous influence in architecture.   
   
I'm sorry, I don't recall reading this book by Wolfe. But anyway, I can't agree with this. The modern architecture (including the Bauhaus) represents a new way of understanding and organizing space. Which doesn't mean it didn't have its (big) problems... And it was not easy for me to understand the great contributions of modern architecture (I went to architecture school). [This book](http://web.archive.org/web/20050810074530/http:/www.amazon.com/exec/obidos/tg/detail/-/0262680378/002-2743001-2411231?v=glance), a collection of articles written by Colin Rowe, helped me understanding many questions, but I'm afraid it's a bit too 'heavy'/'academic' for non-starters.   
   
\> But in typography I think it has more of a mixed legacy - some good, some bad.   
   
OK, I think I agree.   
In any case, let me clarify this: Bauhaus architecture was one thing, Bauhaus typography was another. The contributions of Bauhaus to architecture are mostly exclusively related to architeture. And, FWIW, I think Bauhaus was more important to architecture than to typography...

The biggest problem with 'Bauhaus' typography (and note that the biggest proponent of asymetric typography, Tschichold, was not involved with the Bauhaus) is that it is very hard to do well. Only a handful of people produced really good modernist typography: more of it was sterile. I suspect that the same is true of architecture, although in that field one should take into account materials and building techniques as well as aesthetics when one talks about what constitutes modern.

\>The modern architecture (including the Bauhaus) represents a new way of understanding and organizing space.   
   
I am willing to accept from you, Eduardo, that there is a lot to be learned from the experiments of the Bauhaus. My experience is that their actual buildings, though, are emotionally cold and inhospitable. Tom Wolfe's book, which this thread started with, argues that the Bauhaus people where so good at convincing people of their superior taste that they paid for buildings that very few people liked, and many detested.   
   
In the US, when the Bauhaus influence started waning - I guess by the end of the 70's - new buildings started looking a lot better. To me the Bauhaus is a period of bad taste and bad buildings, and kind of inverse Victorianism, which I also dislike.   
   
I haven't studied the history, either in architecture or typography, but of course we are surrounded by the stuff in one way or another. I not infrequently see some very spare, bare bones typography looking good, but very rarely architecture.   
   
The use of Sans serif titling faces with serif text faces is I am guessing an indirect legacy of Bauhaus, and it often works well.

Hugo, first let me try to explain what may be misleading in what   
I wrote: not �opposed to the Bauhaus�, but, _in some senses,_ to   
Bauhaus typography. And when I mentioned �Swiss typography�   
(a term almost as loaded as �international style�...) was as a   
conspicuous example of a more general spirit. The �Swiss school�   
itself, BTW, was not monolithic (one of the things Maldonado advises   
against is the monolithical assessment of modern architecture,   
and we should take the same care when talking about typography).   
   
To answer you, let me quote one of the leaders of the modernists   
of the fifties, Max Bill [ from a �dialogue� of texts that happened   
in 1946: Bill, in his �On typography�, attacked Tschichold for his   
ideological about-face, Tschichold then responded with his �Glaube   
und Wirklichkeit� (�Faith and reality�). Both texts are fundamental,   
and, even though I side with Bill ; ) I recognize that Tschichold�s   
is brilliant. ] Anyway, on to Bill. He attacked the modernists of the   
twenties and thirties, Bauhausians also, for, among other things,   
   
�that which constituted fashionable accessories: the thick rules,   
the fillets, the huge bullets, the overdimensioned folios, and other   
such attributes [...] all these elements are useless and superfluous   
when the disposition itself is correctly organized, when the groups   
of words are placed in just relations of proportion.� (sorry if this   
sounds convoluted � I�m freely translating from a French translation   
of the German original).   
   
And I add: for justified composition (the Bauhausians didn�t do   
unjustified setting): the �perfect rectangle� was seen as an   
inheritance from the old typography, and a purely formalist device,   
since it goes against the natural, organic spacing of letters and   
words.   
   
In a nutshell: the Bauhausians were seen as formalists by the   
later modernists, who saw themselves as functionalists. The same   
reasoning used for typography can be applied to type design: while   
one can easily (but not very accurately) associate the Bauhaus with   
Paul Renner�s Futura, or (somewhat more correctly) with Bayer�s   
and Joost Schmidt�s experiments, the geometrical sanses were   
rejected by the later modernists as formalist, �artistic� letterforms.   
They would prefer the anonymous �jobbing� grotesks of the late   
19th century. And while Emil Ruder, for instance, saw the release   
of Univers almost as a holy grail of typography � a grotesk with   
high design qualities �, there were still those who would regard   
it as being too �authored�.   
   
Hope that helps.

_Your theory of his reasons for returning to classical typography conflict with mine however. Do you have source on that. I am very interested in him and his works. Also, as you know, Tschichold and I had a mutual friend._   
   
In what I've read of Tschichold's own writing, he never rejects asymetric typography; rather, he rejects his early ideological insistence on asymetric typography, and acknowledges that both asymetric and classical typography have their place, with the latter being most appropriate for books. I think it is important to look at the kind of material Tschichold was designing at different points in his career, and that the move to classical typography coincides with a move from advertising and what we would now call 'identity' design (e.g. stationery) to book design -- and book design of a specific kind: predominantly literary texts in octavo format.   
   
I have an interesting German book that combines Tschichold's writings -- illustrated with samples of his work -- from both halves of his career. Most English language publications, excepting Ruari Maclean's not very good biography, deal with either his asymetric typography _or_ his classical book design, as determined by the interest/bias of the translator or publisher. The German book is better, I think, because it conveys the consistency of Tschichold's attention to detail and quality, and makes one realise how this, not apparently opposing styles, is really key to understanding what Tschichold was about. In his early career, he developed asymetric typography to a very high level, and wrote books urging other typographers to follow suit. In his later career, he applied exactly the same level of quality to classical typography, and wrote what amount to style guides that would enable other typographers to achieve pleasing results. This is why I think the relative ease of achieving such results in the classical style, compared the more difficult task of achieving beauty in asymetric typography, was an important factor in Tschichold's _volte face_, especially as it is expressed in pedagogical efforts such as the essays in _The form of the book._ The fact that he developed his classical book design techniques in the context of the Penguin publishing programme is also interesting, and suggests a context in which mass-production of attractive typography, achievable by designers and printers following style guides, would become preferable to more difficult works requiring individual genius of the kind Tschichold himself had demonstrated in his early career.

I am telling you about Nick because I have no reason to believe he has passed away and probably still lives in British Columbia.   
   
But I have a little story about Swiss training. Nick taught me how to set type. Part of which is, sadly I report, distributing types correctly back into their case.   
   
Certainly this is not the end of the story but it is as far as I dare tell.

I don't know how they deal with disobedient printers in Switzerland or Brazil, but this taken from Savage's _A dictionary of the art of printing,_ London 1841:   
   
_Every chapel_ [a kind of local guild of typesetters and printers working together in a single printing office] _is haunted by an imaginary spirit, named Ralph; and when any person refuses to obey it's mandates, this spirit begins to_ walk _as it is termed. The first act is, in general, to hide the offender's composing stick; if this does not answer, his galleys are secreted; then the page cords, which secure his work, are cut, and his labour rendered more than useless, because he has to distribute his pie_ [spilled type] _as well as recompose his matter; if he still remains contumacious, the whole of the types in his case are transposed, so that he cannot proceed in his business; and if he should still set the chapel at defiance, he is smoked, all the members of the chapel surrounding his frame; each with a lighted match of brimstone, and singing a doleful ditty..._   
   
And from Moxon's _Mechanick Exercises,_ 1683:   
   
_...and the Penalty for the breach of any of these Laws and Customs is in Printers Language called a_ Solace. _... But if the Delinquent prov'd Obstinate or Refractory, and would not pay his Solace at the Price of the Chappel, they_ Solac'd _him. The manner of Solacing, thus. The Workmen take him by force, and lay him on his Belly athwart the Correcting-stone, and held him there while another of the Work-men with a Paper-board, gave him_ 10l. and a purse_, viz. Eleven blows on his Buttocks; which he laid according to his own mercy. For Tradition tells us, that about 50 years ago was one Solaced with so much violence, that he presently Pissed Blood; and shortly after dyed of it._

Hi Brian   
   
I too very much like Bauhaus-inspired architecture, but I also loved Tom Wolfe's book. It's a really fascinating and well-developed argument.   
   
Another book you may like is Prince Charles'   
"A Vision of Britain: A Personal View of Architecture." Here's a couple of lines I got off Amazon's website about it: "The Prince's central point is that modern architecture has lost sight of its surroundings. Rather than creating structures that harmonize with their location, using local materials and respecting the history of the site, many modern buildings seem determined to draw attention to themselves -- or rather, to their architects. Like any art, architecture is a matter of taste. But while you can hide a bad statue or painting, an ugly building is a blot on the landscape that's darn hard to avoid."   
   
I read this book way back when it was published -- I think in the mid 1980s. It caused quite a stir at the time, but now his argument seems pretty sensible. The book also includes some fairly decent drawings by the prince himself.
